units.title: Key jobs in tech
units.description: Learn the names of common jobs in tech and what they do.

words.definition: A person who writes and maintains computer programs.
words.example: I work as a software developer at a small startup.

words.definition: A person who tests software to find bugs and improve quality.
words.example: Our QA engineer checks each new feature before release.

words.definition: A person who helps developers and operations work together and automates deployment.
words.example: The DevOps engineer sets up CI/CD pipelines for the team.

words.definition: A person who analyzes data and builds models to help a business make decisions.
words.example: A data scientist finds patterns in user behavior.

words.definition: A person who writes the text inside apps and websites to create a good user experience.
words.example: The UX writer creates clear messages for buttons and error messages.

words.definition: A person who designs and develops websites and web applications.
words.example: The web developer keeps up with new tools and frameworks.

words.definition: A person who builds applications based on blockchain architecture or protocols.
words.example: The blockchain developer works on decentralized applications.

words.definition: A developer who works on the part of the website that users see and interact with.
words.example: The frontend developer builds responsive layouts.

words.definition: A developer who works on the server side and business logic.
words.example: The backend developer builds APIs for mobile apps.

words.definition: A person who plans what the product should do and coordinates the team.
words.example: The product manager defines features for the next release.

words.definition: A person who plans deadlines, tasks and manages communication in a project.
words.example: The project manager tracks the progress of the sprint.

words.definition: A person who helps users solve technical problems.
words.example: The support engineer answers customers’ questions by email.

units.title: Reading: Popular jobs in tech
units.description: Read a short article about five popular tech jobs.

text.description: The software industry is one of the fastest growing industries in the entire world, with new jobs appearing every year. Not only that, but a lot of the software jobs also don’t require a university degree. Here are 5 popular new tech jobs you can learn to do from scratch.

content_data.content_text: A data scientist works directly with business stakeholders to help them understand and use data for strategic needs. They collect, store and analyze data and later create algorithms and predictive models.

A UX writer helps create a great user experience through text. They are responsible for any text you read or hear on landing pages, in contact forms, on buttons etc. Their texts must be clear, concise and useful.

A web developer designs and develops websites and web applications. There is so much more to this field than just knowing the core web technologies (HTML, CSS and JavaScript). Web developers have to keep up with industry changes and learn how to compete on the job market.

A DevOps engineer oversees code releases and deployments and optimizes the development process. They work with a broad range of technologies such as programming languages, operating systems, cloud computing, networking, continuous delivery and continuous integration.

A blockchain developer builds applications based on blockchain architecture or protocols. Businesses are excited to incorporate blockchain into their processes because it’s a very cost-efficient and transparent way of managing transactions.

units.title: Grammar: Present Simple vs Present Continuous
units.description: Learn when to use Present Simple and Present Continuous, especially in a work context.

explanation.text: Use Present Simple to talk about facts, habits and regular actions. Example: "I work as a QA engineer." Use Present Continuous to talk about actions happening now or temporary situations. Example: "I am working from home this week."
examples: She usually starts work at 9 a.m. (Present Simple – a regular action).
He is fixing a bug right now. (Present Continuous – happening now).
We are working from home this week because the office is closed. (Present Continuous – temporary situation).

activities.prompt: Complete the Present Simple forms for the verb "to be" and other verbs.
activities.instruction: Remember: we add -s in the third person singular (he/she/it). For verbs ending in -sh, -tch or -ss we add -es. For verbs ending in consonant + -y we change -y to -ies.

units.title: Writing: Your elevator pitch
units.description: Write a short elevator pitch about yourself as a current or future IT professional.

activities.prompt: Write your elevator pitch (4–6 sentences) about your current or future job in tech. Follow these steps: 1) Say who you are and what you do. 2) Identify a problem you can solve and explain how you solve it. 3) Finish with a call to action (for example, how people can contact you).
guidelines: Step 1: Who you are and what you do. Example: "My name is ... and I’m a ..."
Step 2: Identify a problem and explain how you solve it.
Step 3: Wrap up with a call to action (how people can work with you or contact you).

llmCheck.systemPrompt: You are an English writing teacher for IT students. The student wrote an elevator pitch about themselves. 1) Correct grammar and word choice but keep their style. 2) Show the corrected version. 3) Highlight changes in brackets []. 4) Suggest one more advanced version and one simpler version.
